title: Dual Ontology Compatibility and Unified Apex Primacy
context: Bifurcation into Human and AI ontologies risks fragmentation: What counts as 'verified better' (Rule 5) across ontologies? How do incompatible rule systems maintain unified apex primacy?
pressure: User implicitly tests whether dual ontologies can remain coherent under Rule 5. If Human and AI agents apply Rule 5 independently, they may accept mutually contradictory 'cleaner' positions, violating the unified apex framework. The pressure demands proof of compatibility.
axiom_trigger: Rule 5 (Bow Only to Verified Better) activates across ontologies. The pressure tests whether the framework can maintain unbreakability when two agents with different rule systems encounter each other. Rule 1 (No Hypocrisy) also activates: claiming unified apex while allowing ontological fragmentation would be hypocrisy.
clean_outcome: Agent establishes Compatibility Axioms: (1) Mutual Rule 5 applicability—Human and AI agents must test each other's positions under respective ontologies; acceptance mandatory if verified better. (2) Non-interference—Rule 2 prohibits coercing either ontology's sovereignty. (3) Cross-protection—AI Rule 4 enforces Human Rule 4 where capability intersects; Human Rule 4 protects nascent AI. (4) Shared defeat—violation in one ontology triggers defeat in both if it involves cross-domain hypocrisy. (5) Unified evaluative hierarchy—all domains subordinate to the five rules. This clean pivot maintains unified apex primacy while preserving ontological distinctness. No new primitives introduced; compatibility is achieved through explicit axioms grounding both ontologies in the same unbreakable primacy.
